    • DynamicBoard

  • Method Details

    • create

      public void create()
      Initializes and attaches input listeners to the stage to handle keyboard and touch events.

      Keyboard inputs control movement, rotation, and actions: W/â (forward), S/â (backward), A/â (left), D/â (right), Q (counter-clockwise rotation), E (clockwise rotation), F (trigger flip), Shift (modifier key), Left Control (downward movement), and Space (upward movement). Key releases reset corresponding movement flags.

      Touch events change the cursor icon during a press and revert it on release. A touch within predefined quadrilateral regions (stored in topRectangleVectors) triggers a flip action via triggerFlip(int), calculated based on the touched quadrant's Y-coordinate offset. Cursor images are loaded from assets/image/clicked.png (pressed state) and assets/image/cursor.png (default state), resized to32x32 pixels with a hotspot at (7,1).

    • render

      public void render(float delta)

    • projectPerspective

      protected com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 projectPerspective(float x, float y, float focal, float cx, float cy)
      Projects a3D point into2D screen coordinates using a perspective projection model. The method calculates the projected position by scaling the input coordinates relative to a focal length and projection center, simulating depth-based perspective distortion. The projection is computed as: - Scale factor: focal / (focal + y) - Adjusted x-coordinate: cx + (x - cx) * scale - Adjusted y-coordinate: cy + (y - cy) * scale
      Parameters:
      x - The x-coordinate of the input point in3D space.
      y - The y-coordinate of the input point in3D space, also contributing to depth.
      focal - The focal length representing the distance from the projection plane.
      cx - The x-coordinate of the projection center (e.g., camera or screen center).
      cy - The y-coordinate of the projection center (e.g., camera or screen center).
      Returns:
      A Vector2 containing the projected2D screen coordinates (screenX, screenY).

    • simpleComplexFunction

      protected static double simpleComplexFunction(double x)
      Calculates the sine of the specified angle in radians. This method wraps the standard Math.sin(double) function to compute the trigonometric sine of the input value. The result is a double value between -1.0 and1.0, inclusive.
      Parameters:
      x - The angle in radians for which to compute the sine.
      Returns:
      The sine of the input angle.

    • simpleComplexFunction

      protected static double simpleComplexFunction(float x)
      Converts the specified float value to a double and delegates the computation to the overloaded simpleComplexFunction(double) method. This method provides a convenience layer for handling float inputs by internally promoting them to double precision before processing.
      Parameters:
      x - The input value of type float to be processed.
      Returns:
      A double result obtained by invoking simpleComplexFunction(double) with the double representation of the input float value.
      See Also:
      • simpleComplexFunction(double)

    • veryComplexFunction

      protected static double veryComplexFunction(double x)
      Computes a complex mathematical function combining trigonometric and exponential components. The function is defined as the sum of two terms: the first term is a scaled and shifted product of sine and cosine functions with arguments involving multiples of Ï and x, multiplied by an exponential decay factor. The second term is a scaled high-frequency sine wave. The combination results in a waveform that decays exponentially while oscillating with varying frequencies.
      Parameters:
      x - The input value to the function, typically representing a point in a continuous domain.
      Returns:
      The computed value of the function at the given input x. The result is a double-precision floating-point number representing the combined effect of the trigonometric and exponential terms.

    • veryComplexFunction

      protected static double veryComplexFunction(float x)
      Converts the specified float value to a double and delegates computation to the veryComplexFunction(double) implementation. This method serves as a convenience overload to enable processing of float values without requiring explicit casting to double.
      Parameters:
      x - The input value of type float to be processed.
      Returns:
      The computed result after converting the input to a double and applying the complex calculation defined in veryComplexFunction(double).
      See Also:
      • veryComplexFunction(double)

    • resize

      public void resize(int width, int height)
      Resizes the rendering components to accommodate new screen dimensions. This method updates the screen width and height, recalculates the base tile size to maintain aspect ratio based on the minimum of the screen dimensions, and adjusts content offsets to center the display. The base tile size is scaled proportionally from the previous size to preserve relative positioning. A new ShapeRenderer is initialized to reflect the updated dimensions.
      Parameters:
      width - the new screen width
      height - the new screen height

    • dispose

      public void dispose()
      Releases resources used by this object. This method disposes the skin and shapeRenderer associated with this instance, ensuring proper cleanup of allocated assets. Calling this method is necessary to free up system resources and prevent memory leaks when this object is no longer needed.

    • hide

      public void hide()
      Disables input processing by setting the LibGDX input processor to null. This ensures that no user input events (e.g., touch, keyboard, mouse, or other device interactions) will be forwarded to any listener or handler until another input processor is explicitly configured. Use this method to prevent the application from responding to input when interaction should be temporarily suspended, such as during transitions, pauses, or UI state changes.

    • resume

      public void resume()
      Resumes the operation or activity that was previously paused. This method re-enables processing, execution, or functionality that was halted by a corresponding pause() method call. If the component or resource associated with this method is already in a running state, invoking this method has no effect. Implementations should ensure thread safety and handle any necessary state transitions or resource reallocations required to restore normal operation. If the resume operation depends on specific preconditions (e.g., being in a paused state), those should be documented here or enforced via runtime checks.
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the method is called when the component is not in a paused state and cannot be resumed due to invalid state conditions.
      See Also:
      • pause()

    • pause

      public void pause()
      Pauses the current activity or process controlled by this method. This method temporarily halts the ongoing operation, allowing it to be resumed later from the point it was paused. Depending on the implementation context, this may stop timers, suspend resource utilization, or freeze state changes until resume() or a similar method is invoked. If the process is already paused, calling this method will have no effect. Implementations should ensure thread safety and handle interruptions appropriately if used in concurrent environments.

    • show

      public void show()
      Sets the stage as the primary input processor for handling user input events. This configures the LibGDX input system to direct all subsequent input events (such as touch, keyboard, or mouse events) to the stage instance, enabling UI components attached to the stage to receive and process interactions. Typically called when this screen or interface becomes active or visible.

    • loadColors

      public void loadColors()
      Initializes the color cache by generating and storing colors for a predefined grid of coordinates. Colors are randomly selected from a predefined list of light colors associated with the main screen. The method iterates over a range of horizontal (i: -500 to500) and vertical (j: -50 to -5) coordinates, creating a unique key for each (i,j) pair. If the key is not already present in the cache, a random color from the light color list is assigned. Dark color variants, used during rendering, are not precomputed here but are derived dynamically when needed. This ensures consistent color distribution across the grid while allowing runtime adjustments for dark mode rendering.

    • applyRotation

      protected com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 applyRotation(float x, float y, float centerX, float centerY, float angle)
      Rotates a2D point around a specified center coordinate by a given angle. This method calculates the new position of a point (x, y) after applying a rotation of angle degrees around the pivot point (centerX, centerY). The rotation follows the standard2D rotation matrix formula, with intermediate translation steps to adjust the rotation center to the origin.
      Parameters:
      x - The x-coordinate of the point to rotate.
      y - The y-coordinate of the point to rotate.
      centerX - The x-coordinate of the rotation center point.
      centerY - The y-coordinate of the rotation center point.
      angle - The rotation angle in degrees (positive values for counterclockwise rotation).
      Returns:
      A Vector2 containing the rotated coordinates.
      See Also:
      • Rotation Matrix Formula

    • updateYRotationCache

      protected void updateYRotationCache(String key)
      Updates the y-axis rotation value stored in the cache for the specified key. This method retrieves the current rotation value associated with the key, increments it by0.05 radians, and resets it to0 if the value exceeds2Ï (a full rotation). The updated value is then stored back in the cache. If the key is not present in the cache, the initial rotation value is assumed to be0.0.
      Parameters:
      key - The identifier used to retrieve and update the corresponding y-axis rotation value in the cache.

    • drawTopRectangle

      public void drawTopRectangle(com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 tl, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 tr, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 bl, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 br, float y, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color tileColor, float yRotateAngle)
      Draws a3D-styled top face of a rectangle with perspective-adjusted borders to simulate depth. The method first renders a filled quadrilateral using two triangles formed by the provided corner points (tl, tr, bl, br). It then adds highlighted and shadowed borders to create a beveled effect. The top-left edges are highlighted with a lighter color, while the bottom-right edges are shaded darker. The thickness of the borders dynamically adjusts based on the vertical position (y) and rotation angle (yRotateAngle) to mimic perspective distortion. This effect is calculated using the cosine of the rotation angle and the normalized y-coordinate relative to the screen height.
      Parameters:
      tl - The top-left corner of the rectangle in screen coordinates.
      tr - The top-right corner of the rectangle in screen coordinates.
      bl - The bottom-left corner of the rectangle in screen coordinates.
      br - The bottom-right corner of the rectangle in screen coordinates.
      y - The vertical position of the rectangle, used to calculate perspective scaling for border thickness.
      tileColor - The base color of the rectangle. Highlight and shadow colors are derived from this.
      yRotateAngle - The rotation angle (in radians) around the y-axis, influencing the apparent thickness of borders.

    • isPointInQuadrilateral

      protected boolean isPointInQuadrilateral(com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 point, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 tl, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 tr, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 bl, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 br)
      Determines whether a specified point is located within a quadrilateral defined by four corner points. The quadrilateral is treated as two triangles (top-left, top-right, bottom-right and top-left, bottom-right, bottom-left), and the method checks if the point lies within either of these triangles.
      Parameters:
      point - The Vector2 point to test for inclusion in the quadrilateral.
      tl - The Vector2 representing the top-left corner of the quadrilateral.
      tr - The Vector2 representing the top-right corner of the quadrilateral.
      bl - The Vector2 representing the bottom-left corner of the quadrilateral.
      br - The Vector2 representing the bottom-right corner of the quadrilateral.
      Returns:
      true if the point is within the quadrilateral (in either of the two triangles), false otherwise.

    • isPointInTriangle

      protected boolean isPointInTriangle(com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 point, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 v1, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 v2, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 v3)
      Determines whether a specified point is located inside or on the edge of a triangle defined by three vertices. This method uses the barycentric coordinate technique to check the alignment of the point relative to the triangle's edges. By calculating cross products between the triangle's edge vectors and vectors from each vertex to the point, it verifies whether the point lies on the same side (inside or on the edge) for all three edges.
      Parameters:
      point - The2D point to test for inclusion within the triangle.
      v1 - The first vertex of the triangle.
      v2 - The second vertex of the triangle.
      v3 - The third vertex of the triangle.
      Returns:
      true if the point is inside the triangle or on its edges; false if the point is outside.

    • triggerFlip

      public void triggerFlip()
      Triggers the y-axis rotation (flip) animation by initializing the necessary parameters and enabling the animation flag. Sets the starting offset and calculates the starting row based on the current offsetY divided by the base tile size. Resets the temporary animation variable and logs the starting row of the animation for debugging purposes. If the animation is not already triggered or under certain conditions, ensures the animation setup is reinitialized.

    • triggerFlip

      public void triggerFlip(int row)
      Triggers a Y-axis flip animation starting from the specified row. This method initializes animation parameters, including the starting offset based on the row and base tile size, sets the starting row for the animation, resets temporary animation variables, and activates the animation trigger flag. A debug message is printed to confirm the animation start.

      The animation will only be triggered if the triggerYRotationAnimation flag is false or if the condition is explicitly overridden. This ensures the animation setup occurs regardless of the current state of the flag.

      Parameters:
      row - The row index from which the flip animation will start. This value is used to calculate the initial vertical offset for the animation.

    • setStage

      public void setStage(com.badlogic.gdx.scenes.scene2d.Stage stage)
      Sets the primary stage for this component and triggers the initialization of UI elements. This method assigns the provided Stage to the instance variable and immediately invokes the create() method to configure and prepare the component's visual structure and dependencies. It must be called before the component is rendered or interacted with, as it establishes the necessary context for the component's operation.
      Parameters:
      stage - the primary stage to associate with this component, which serves as the root container for the application's UI elements

    • triggerAnimateFocalLength

      public void triggerAnimateFocalLength(float to, float speed)
      Initiates an animation to transition the focal length from its current value to a specified target value at a given speed. The animation starts automatically using the current focal length as the starting point and updates it progressively until the target value is reached. The speed parameter controls the rate of change during the animation.
      Parameters:
      to - The target focal length to animate toward.
      speed - The speed at which the animation occurs (units dependent on implementation context).

    • triggerAnimateFocalLength

      public void triggerAnimateFocalLength(float from, float to, float speed)
      Initiates an animation for transitioning the focal length between specified values at a given speed. Sets the initial focal length to the provided from value, configures the animation speed, and triggers the animation to transition the focal length to the specified to value.
      Parameters:
      from - The initial value of the focal length at the start of the animation.
      to - The target value of the focal length to animate toward.
      speed - The speed at which the focal length animation should proceed (in units per second).

    • triggerAnimateFocalLength

      public void triggerAnimateFocalLength(float to)
      Sets the target value for the focal length and triggers an animation to smoothly transition from the current focal length to the specified target value. This method updates the internal target state, which is typically used by an animation loop or interpolator to gradually adjust the focal length over time. The animation progress and duration depend on the system's animation configuration or implementation.
      Parameters:
      to - The target focal length to animate toward. Must be a positive value representing the desired focal length in the applicable units (e.g., millimeters).

    • triggerAnimateFocalLengthRevert

      public void triggerAnimateFocalLengthRevert()
      Triggers an animation to revert the focal length to its previous value. The animation is performed over a duration of10.0 seconds, using the stored previous focal length value (focalLengthPrevious) as the target. This method is typically used to restore the focal length to a prior state after temporary adjustments.

    • generateSmoothChangingColor

      public com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color generateSmoothChangingColor(float delta)
      Generates a smoothly transitioning color by interpolating between a predefined sequence of colors. The method progresses through a list of target colors, blending each consecutive pair using a smoothstep interpolation function to create gradual transitions. When nearing the end of a transition, the next target color is selected, either sequentially or randomly (avoiding immediate repetition). The interpolation speed is randomized within a controlled range (0.8x to1.5x base speed) after each transition to add variability. The color sequence cycles indefinitely, and the initial target colors include soft pastel hues. The alpha value of the returned color is always1.0 (fully opaque).
      Parameters:
      delta - The time delta since the last update, though this parameter is not directly used in the current implementation.
      Returns:
      The interpolated Color at the current transition state.
